properties.name: Biltmore
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11Ashville, North CarolinaThis beautiful mansion is found in Asheville, North Carolina. It was built and founded from 1888-1895. The architects for this home are Richard Morris and Frederick Law Olmsted. It was built with a Renaissance style. The house was lived in until 1956, when it was permanently opened to the public as a house museum. Visitors from all over the world continue to visit and love the 70,000 gallon indoor swimming pool, bowling alley, turn-of-the-century exercise equipment, two-story library, and other rooms filled with artworks, furniture and 19th-century novelties such as elevators, forced-air heating, centrally-controlled clocks, fire alarms and an intercom system. It remains a major tourist attraction in western North Carolina, with more than 1 million visitors each year.

properties.name: Buckingham Palace
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11London, UK The Buckingham Palace is the home of the British monarch. The palace holds state events, royal entertaining and it is a major tourist attraction. It is a national landmark that is very special to the British people. It was originally known as Buckingham House and was the centerpiece, which the palace was built around. It was built for the Duke of Buckingham in 1703 and bought by George III in 1761 for himself. It officially became the royal palace of the British monarch when Queen Victoria came to power in 1837. When he owned the house it was known as “The Queen’s House”. Later it was sometimes called “Buck House”. John Nash and Edward Blore enlarged it over the years. The last additions were made in the late 19th and early 20th century. In the early 19th-century interior designers used bright blues and pink lapis. Many smaller rooms are furnished with a Chinese style with furniture and fittings brought from the Royal Pavilion at Brighton and from Carlton House following the death of King George IV. The staterooms form the center of the working Palace and are used regularly by Queen Elizabeth II and members of the royal family for official and state entertaining. Buckingham Palace is one of the world\'s most familiar buildings and more than 50,000 people visit the palace each year, They visit as guests to banquets, lunches, dinners, receptions and the royal garden parties,

properties.name: Notre Dame Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11parisNotre Dame is a Gothic cathedral and is still used as a Roman Catholic cathedral. It is also the seat of the Archbishop of Paris. This beautiful building is just one example of French Gothic architecture. It was also one of the first Gothic cathedrals and took most of the Gothic period to build. Its sculptures and stained glass give this cathedrals show naturalism. Viollet le Duc restored and saved the Notre Dame from destruction. The name Notre Dame means "Our Lady" in French. The cathedral suffered destruction during the radical phase of the French Revolution in the 1790s, when much of its religious imagery was damaged or destroyed. During the 19th century, a restoration project was completed, returning the cathedral to its previous state.

properties.name: Official start of Route 66 in Chicago
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11398 E. Jackson St, Chicago, IllinoisRoute 66 is also known as U.S. Route 66, The Main Street of America, The Mother Road and the Will Rogers Highway. It is one of the first federal routes. US 66 was finished on November 11, 1926, but signs did not go up until the following year. It originally ran from Chicago, Illinois, through Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California, before ending in Los Angeles. It was a total of 2,448 miles long. It was not completely paved until 1938. Avery, one of the founders, wanted the route to have a round number so he asked if the number could be 60, but because of other routes Avery setteled on 66. This number would make it easier to remember and to say. The beginning of the end for Route 66 came in 1956 when they signed the Interstate Highway Act given by President Dwight Eisenhower. When Eisenhower was a general fighting in the Euoropean theater during World War II he was impressed by Germany’s high speed highways, which they called Autobahnen. Eisenhower wanted a similar system of roads for the US in which one could easily drive at a high speed from one end of the country to the other without stopping. This would also make it easier to move troops if there was a national emergency. Throughout its 60 years of existence, Route 66 was always changing. As highway engineering became more advanced, engineers constantly found more direct routes between cities and towns. When there was an increase in traffic Illinois began widening US 66 to four lanes through the intire state.. By the early-to-mid 1950s, Missouri also increased its sections of US 66 to four lanes with bypasses. Most of the newer four-lane 66 paving in both states was upgraded to freeway status in later years.

properties.name: Savannah, Georgia
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11Savannah, GeorgiaSavannah, Georgia was established in 1733 and was the first colonial and state capital of Georgia. It is the birthplace of Juliette Gardon Low, the founder of Girl Scouts of the USA, Telfair Academy of the Arts and Sciences, one of the souths first public museums, the first African Baptist Church, the oldest in America, and Temple Mickve Israel, the third oldest synagogue in America. It has 1,759 people per sq. mile. Some interesting facts about Savannah is that in 2002 the American Institue of Parapsychology named Savannah as "America\'s Most Haunted City." This is because of Savannah\'s history with fires, plauges, wars and voodoo. Haint blue appears on most old door frames because it was said to ward off evil spirits. Also Savannah has appeared in some huge films including Forrest Gump.

properties.name: Smokey Mountains
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11GatlinburgThe Great Smoky Mountains are a major mountain range in the southern part of the Appalachian Mountains, and bordering the western side of the Blue Ridge Mountains. It is also called the Smoky Mountains or the Smokies, they are located at the border between Tennessee and North Carolina, and are west of the Eastern Continental Divide. The Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a huge feature of the mountains. It was built as a national park in the 1930s, and has over 9 million visits per year. It is the most-visited national park in the United States. Much of the range is also protected as the Nantahala National Forest, Pisgah National Forest, and Cherokee National Forest outside of the park. The name of the area comes from the natural haze that often hangs over it. As in the Blue Ridge Mountains to the east. Hydrocarbons produced by trees and other local vegetation, and higher humidity, produce a bluish color to the sky. Visibility now is reduced by smog from both the Southeastern United States and the Midwest, and smog forecasts are delivered daily by the Environmental Protection Agency for both nearby Knoxville, Tennessee, and Asheville, North Carolina.

properties.name: Statue of Liberty
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11New York CityThe Statue of Liberty also known as Liberty Enlightening the Word. She is a huge statue that was given to us as a gift from France on October 28, 1886. It is now at Liberty Island which is actually on the New Jersey side of the New York Harbor. It is a welcome to all visitors, immagrants, and returning Americans. This is a copper patina-clad statue that was given to show the friendship from France to the U.S. The sclupter was Frederic Auguste Bartholdi and Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the designer of the Eiffel Tower, engineered the internal structure. Eugene Viollet-le-Duc picked the choice of copper in the statue\'s construction. The statue is of a robed woman holding a lit flame, and is made of a sheeting of pure copper, It stands on a rectangular stone pedestal with a foundation in the shape of an eleven-pointed star. The statue is 151 feet tall, with the pedestal and foundation, it is 305 feet tall. The Statue of Liberty\'s appearance comes from Livertas, who was the acient Roman goddess of freedom from slavery, oppression and tyranny. The seven spikes on the crown represent the Seven Seas and seven continents. Her torch represents enlightenment. The tablet in her hand represents knowledge and shows the date of the nation\'s birth, July 4, 1776.

properties.name: The Beaches
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11St. AugustineSt. Augustine is one of the nation\'s oldest cities. It also holds the title of the nation\'s most charming. Known as the "Ancient City," Saint Augustine is located between North East and Central East Florida and is convenient to Jacksonville, Orlando, and Daytona airports. North Florida has a year-round mild climate perfect for walking Saint Augustine\'s historic district, with its cobblestone streets, cafes, unique shops and bed-and-breakfast inns. You can experience the beauty of an early morning that buzzes with locals and tourists setting out to walk and explore historic landmarks such as: Castillo de San Marcos, Fort Matanzas, and Flagler College.

properties.name: The Sydney Opera House
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11sydneyThe Sydney Opera House is located in Sydney, Australia. It was made a UNESCO World Heritage Site on June 28, 2007. It was designed by Danish architect Jorn Utzon and Ove Arup & Partners. The Sydney Opera House is one of the world\'s most bold 20th century buildings, and one of the most famous performing arts stages in the world. It is located on Bennelong Point in Sydney Harbour, which is close to the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The building and its surroundings are one of the best known locations in Australia. This Opera House is home to touring theatre, ballet, musical productions, Opera Australia, the Sydney Theatre Company and the Sydney Symphony. The Sydney Opera House is an example of modern design, with a series of large precast concrete \'shells\' forming the roofs of the structure. The Opera House covers 4.5 acres of land. It is 605 feet long and about 388 feet wide at its widest point. It is supported on 588 concrete piers sunk up to 25 metres below sea level. The Concert Hall and Opera Theatre are each contained in the two largest groups of shells, and the other theatres are located on the sides of the shell groupings. The Concert Hall has 2,679 seats and is the home of the Sydney Symphony and other concert presenters. It contains the Sydney Opera House Grand Organ, the largest mechanical organ in the world with over 10,000 pipes.The Opera Theatre is a proscenium theatre with 1,547 seats, and is the Sydney home of Opera Australia and The Australian Ballet. The Drama Theatre, a proscenium theatre with 544 seats, is used by the Sydney Theatre Company and other dance and theatrical presenters The Playhouse, an end-stage theatre with 398 seats The Studio has a maximum capacity of 400 people, depending on the set up.

properties.name: Trevi Fountain
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11 The Trevi Fountain is the largest fountain standing at 85 feet high and 65 feet wide and the most ambitious of the Baroque fountains of Rome. It is located in the rione of Trevi. In 1629 Pope Urban VIII found that the earlier fountain was insufficiently dramatic and asked Bernini to sketch new designs, but when the Pope died the project was abandoned. In 1730 Pope Clement XII came up with a contest in which Nicola Salvi initially lost to Alessandro Galilei but because the Romans were complaining that a Florentine won Salvi was awarded the commission wnyway. Work began in 1732, and the fountain was completed in 1762, which was long after Clement\'s death.Salvi died in 1751 so with his work half-finished, before he died, he made sure a barber’s sign would not spoil his hard work so he hide his sculpture under a vase. The Trevi Fountain was finished in 1762 by Giuseppe Pannini. The fountain was restored in 1998 in which the stonework was scrubbed and the fountain provided with recirculating pumps. Taming of the waters is the theme of the gigantic scheme. One legend is that if a visitor throws a coin into the fountain they will return to Rome and if you throw two coins a marriage will occur soon. Then if you throw three coins it will lead to a divorce. It is also lucky to throw three coins with your right hand over your left shoulder. About 3,000 Euros are trown in the fountain each day and are collected at night. The money is used to help the needy in Rome. It is illegal to swim in the fountain but that didn’t stop a 40 year old tourist, Roberta from Milan. On April, 22 2007 he jumped in saying, “I was hot. The water belongs to everyone.”

properties.name: Willamsburg, Virginia
properties.description: Posted by Copperboom11Willamsburg, VirginiaWilliamsburg is a city located on the Virginia Peninsula in southeastern Virginia. In 2000 the city had a total population of 11,998. It is bordered by James City County and York County, and is an independent city. The Bureau of Economic Analysis combines the city of Williamsburg with James City County for statistical purposes. It was a 1632 settlement located on high ground on the Peninsula between the James and York rivers. Then renamed Williamsburg after the capital of the Virginia Colony was moved there from Jamestown in 1698. The town received a royal charter as a city in 1722, and was the center of political events in Virginia leading to the American Revolution.
